Name: a460f44c1f73ce2900f505918b61dfff
Position: EU-FORA Fellow chez European Food Safety Authority (EFSA)
Experience: [['EU-FORA Fellow', 'European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) · Contract', 'Aug 2021 - Present · 10 mos', 'Bari, Pouilles, Italie', 'The European Food Risk Assessment (EU-FORA) Fellowship Programme is a key initiative for building the EU’s scientific assessment capacity and knowledge community, enhancing cooperation among Europe’s food safety organisations and between them and EFSA, thus contributing to the harmonisation of food risk assessment practices across Europe. 12-month fellowship granted to work on "Risk Assessment/Risk Communication: understanding the context and addressing Priorities of the future — a learning-by-doing approach", at the National Research Council of Italy - Institute of Sciences of Food Productions (CNR-ISPA), Italy. In the framework of the #FoodSafety4EU project, the fellow gets a comprehensive overview of the risk assessment process and expected challenges for the incoming years, including risk communication aspects, through activites relevant to the following topics: A) harmonization of enforcement practices with emphasis on unregulated hazards and emerging issues B) innovative approaches and models to inform civil society about the risk assessment process. To this purpose, the fellow participates in two “Food Safety Operational Labs” (FSOLabs), i.e. social/living labs in which a working group composed by different actors of the food safety system : - performs a diagnosis of the current situation for each of the above mentioned topics, - co-creates ideas on how to address the diagnosed issues, - sets up specific pilot actions, - evaluates the results of the pilot studies to formulate recommendations and best practices.', 'EU-FORA – The European Food Risk Assessment Fellowship Programme', 'The programme’s principal focus is on chemical and microbiological risk assessment. It is aimed at professionals with a background in biological sciences relevant to food safety and competent organisations with strong capacity in one or more areas of food safety risk assessment. (Note that food safety encompasses risk assessment, risk communication and risk management in any field under EFSA’s remit). Check out the FAQ in the toolbox (right) for more information.'], ['Senior Creative Scientist', 'PROTÉINES XTC · Permanent', 'Sep 2014 - Present · 7 yrs 9 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'Protéines XTC is an independent communication/innovation group created in 1989. Historically specialized in nutrition and public health, the group provides sense-making, science-driven consulting and communication services for major agro-food/health/chemistry compagnies, federations, agencies, organizations. Main missions : - Project management : driving various tools/deliverables creation processes (websites, brochures, posters, etc.) managing briefings, budgets, timings and deliveries - Strategic advising : organization of brainstorming sessions, co-elaboration of action and communication plans and events, KOL meetings preparation. - Crisis management : media monitoring on specific topics, training sessions, implementation of reactive PR/content strategies, public stances and statements elaboration - Nutritional auditing of products. - Science outreach, content writing, editing and curating, on social media, websites, apps. - Quantitative/qualitative studies/surveys on specific topics : methodological design, recruitment, study implementation, data recovering, statistical analyses and interpretation of results - Regulatory, scientific and media monitoring : analysis and comprehensive summaries of data, studies and articles around food, health and environmental topics. - E-influencers and online discussion monitoring (data mining tools : Talkwalker, Radarly), identification and mapping (dataviz : Gephi) Main clients : -Danone : Blédina, Le Grand Forum des Tout-Petits, DNAO -Nestlé Waters -McDonalds France / Global -Intermarché -AMC Distribution (Groupe Casino) -Scamark (Leclerc) -Sodebo -Panzani -Pink Lady -TWDC (Disney Tous en Forme program) -INTERFEL -InterCéréales -SFAE -UIPP / ECPA -BASF -SBM Company -Syngenta -Corteva Agriscience -PlasticsEurope -FEBEA -Hello Tomorrow -OKP4 Smart Farmers', 'Creative scientists & brand activists', 'Des Femmes et des Hommes experts reconnus du secteur : ingénieurs agronomes, nutritionnistes, communicants, prospectivistes, sociologues, etc. qui font de ProtéinesXTC une plateforme de compétences inégalées. Des expertises complémentaires à un haut niveau de compétence : veille et prospectives, benchmark, workshop innovation, études et perceptions consommateurs, stratégie de marque et de contenu, prévention et gestion de crise, relations médias et stratégies d’influence.'], ['Artisan d’art créateur', 'Mimi Und Mimi · Self-employed', 'Mar 2018 - Present · 4 yrs 3 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'Mimi und Mimi is a French hand-knitted, slow-fashion clothing brand. Designing a new methodology for the assessment of differences in children reactions to sensory signals (food smells and visuals), according to their sensitivity to food hedonics (profiled via the online MIAM tool for food pleasure measurement) and their weight status (normal, overweight, obese)."], ['Marketing Research Intern', 'INSEAD', 'Sep 2013 - Mar 2014 · 7 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'Research project under the supervision of Hilke Plassmann (Marketing Professor at INSEAD), between the ISSRC (INSEAD Social Science Research Centre, the INSEAD’s behavioural lab, run by Pierre Chandon), and the Laboratory of Cognitive Neurosciences (Inserm U960 - Ecole Normale Superieure, run by Etienne Koechlin), both located in Paris. Experience: [['PHD', 'PSL Research University', '2017 - 2021 · 4 yrs', 'Paris, Île-de-France, France', 'A minimal (and biophysical) approach to quantify the impact of the genetic context on gene expression.'], ['Cofounder and CEO', 'Unibiome (Peer To Peer Probiotics)', '2016 - 2020 · 4 yrs', 'Région de Paris, France'], ['Visiting Research Fellow', 'Systems Engineering and Evolution Dynamics', '2016 - 2017 · 1 yr', 'Paris, France'], ['Research Intern', 'Harvard Medical School', 'Apr 2016 - Sep 2016 · 6 mos', 'Boston, MA', 'Investigating riboregulators.'], ['Research Intern', 'Institut Curie', 'Jan 2016 - Apr 2016 · 4 mos', 'Paris, France', 'Recent single cell RNAseq data suggest that cancer cells of Ewing’s sarcoma evolve into two subpopulations: a fast and a slow growing one. My project focuses on identifying the driving variables and critical parameters responsible for such a phenotype divergence, through a mechanistic modeling approach.'], ['Research Intern', 'École normale supérieure', 'Oct 2015 - Dec 2015 · 3 mos', 'Paris, France', 'I worked on mathematically model the CRISPR/Cas system in order to predict the best conditions for an improved targeting specificity. This project allows me to potentially be the first author of an interdisciplinary paper grouping my previous experimental results with this theoretical approach.'], ['Research Intern', 'Centre de Recherches Interdisciplinaires - Center for Research and Interdisciplinarity (CRI Paris)', 'Jan 2015 - Sep 2015 · 9 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'This project is the follow-up of some promising results I produced from my work during the iGEM competition (see previous research experience). The goal of the project is to design a new CRISPR/Cas-based screening technique in order to select bacteria in regard to their genotype and phenotype. After the development of the method and a proof of principle in Escherichia coli, the application of the technique in relevant examples is planned, in particular: the isolation of a specific naturally occuring mutant strain of Lactobacillus Acidophilus which would be a new pro- biotic treatment for Crohn’s disease.'], ['Advisor', 'Paris Bettencourt iGEM Team', 'Jan 2015 - Sep 2015 · 9 mos', 'Paris, France', 'My advising role for the 2015 Paris-Bettencourt iGEM team (see previous research experience) mainly consisted in providing guidance for project development, experimental design and team management. This year’s project being oriented towards the metabolic engineering of yeast and bacteria from food microbiome, my assistance was also a lot centered on debugging molecular biology problems and mathematical modeling difficulties.'], ['Research Scientist', 'Paris Bettencourt iGEM Team', 'May 2014 - Nov 2014 · 7 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'The International Genetically Engineered Machines event is a Synthetic Biology competition organized every year at the MIT, Boston, MA. One of the 300 teams around the world is the Paris Bettencourt team. I was selected to be a member of this team in 2014, and I was in charge of applying for the first time the CRISPR/Cas system on bacteria from the skin microbiome in order to perform a population control and therefore re-engineer this complex microbial ecosystem. Our work was rewarded by the the Best New Application prize.'], ['Research Intern', 'Psychiatry and Neuroscience Center of Paris', 'May 2013 - Sep 2013 · 5 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'I worked on an independent project of setting up a Clarity® platform. I adapted the Clarity® protocol and studied Parvalbumin(+) neurons from optogenetic-transgenic mice. I studied the Parvalbumin network in the mouse line Ai27xPV-Cre by performing a three dimensional mapping of the protein through the brain using confocal microscopy with reference to Allen Brain Atlas to produce new theories about neural pathways involving the Parvalbumin protein.']]

Analyse de sélection du modèle (sélection descendante et ascendante) Outils utilisés: Statistique, Épidémiologie, Biomathématiques, logiciel R', 'IGEM-Pasteur Team 2016', 'Jan 2016 - Mar 2017 · 1 yr 3 mos', 'Région de Paris , France', 'I was a member of the IGEM-Pasteur team 2016, "International Genetically Engineered Machine", which is an international student competition organized through Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), the goal for student teams is to develop an innovative project in synthetic biology. We created a new diagnostic device that uses immunology to detect the presence or absence of arboviruses in Aedes aegytpi mosquitoes responsible for outbreaks worldwide such as Zika, Chikungunya or Yellow fever. The goal is to have a better disease tracking to minimize the over-spraying of insecticides, which impacts the environment and leads to the selection of insecticide-resistant mosquitoes. We wanted also to optimize prevention of the spread of these diseases and facilitate quick diagnostics. Our kit is calling Mos(kit)o Kit, it includes a fixed or mobile mosquito trap, a detection device and a precise map of vector hot spots. For the 2016 iGEM\'s giant Jamboree, we have been rewarded for our "Mos(kit)o" project with several prices: -A gold medal -Best Diagnostic project -Best applied design -Best entrepreneurship project And also a nomination for the final of the best project, and a nomination for the best presentation. Apr 2011 · 3 yrs 8 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', "Mes travaux doctoraux ont visé à mieux définir la fonction moléculaire ainsi qu'à identifier de nouveaux interactants de la protéine LYST, responsable d'une maladie autosomique recessive rare du système immunitaire : le syndrome de Chediak Higashi. Cette expérience m'a amenée à développer ma faculté de traitement d’un projet complexe par la définition et le suivi de différentes approches simultanées de la problématique : * Biologie moléculaire : analyse génétique de patients sélectionnés pour leur expression modérée du syndrome ayant conduit à l'identification de mutations faux-sens * Bioinformatique : étude structurale fine par la méthode d'Analyse des Cluster Hydrophobes (HCA) ayant conduit à l'identification d'un nouveau domaine legume-lectine au sein de la protéine LYST * Biochimie : clonage et expression du domaine legume-lectine afin de réaliser un test de liaison de celui-ci sur une puce à sucres (résultats non conclusifs) * Biologie cellulaire : caractérisation des conséquences d'un défaut de LYST dans le trafic intracellulaire par immunofluorescence ayant conduit à l'identification d'un défaut dans la voie de dégradation médiée par les protéines ESCRTs J'ai également été amenée à : * mettre en place des collaborations avec d’autres laboratoires (un laboratoire de bioinformatique - CNRS UMR 7590, IMPMC, Paris - avec lequel nous avons réalisé une publication, ainsi qu’un laboratoire de glycobiologie - CERMAV-UPR 5301, Grenoble) * exercer mon aptitude à la communication scientifique, à l'analyse et à la synthèse de mes résultats lors de la présentation de mon travail à différents congrès et de la rédaction d'articles publiés"], ['Stagiaire en Laboratoire de Recherche', 'PIK - Potsdam institute for Climate Impact Research', 'Apr 2006 - Jul 2006 · 4 mos', 'Région de Potsdam, Allemagne', "Etude de l’impact des changements climatiques sur le développement de la végétation dans le bassin amazonien à l’aide du modèle LPJ (Lund-Potsdam-Jena ; Name: 0a824c77bf6790f7c04873628ad6c0e6
Position: Team Leader - Synthetic Biology
Experience: [['Team Leader - Synthetic Biology', 'Eligo Bioscience', 'Dec 2015 - Present · 6 yrs 6 mos', 'Ville de Paris, Île-de-France, France'], ['PhD student', 'INSERM', 'Oct 2011 - Nov 2015 · 4 yrs 2 mos', 'Center for Interdisciplinary research, Paris', 'I am a PhD student in Inserm U1001 Evolutionnary Systems Biology group.'], ['Advisor', 'iGEM Paris-Bettencourt team 2012', 'May 2012 - Nov 2012 · 7 mos', 'Center for Interdisciplinary research, Paris', 'A synthetic biology project aiming at evaluating the risk of HGT (Horizontal Gene Transfer) in different SynBio applications and developing a new, improved containment system to expand the range of environments where GEOs (Genetically Engineered Organisms) can be used safely. Safety Commendations by the judges at the European iGEM Jamboree (Amsterdam); Best Environment Project Prize and 2nd Runner-Up at the World Jamboree (Boston).'], ['Advisor', 'iGEM Paris-Bettencourt team 2011', 'May 2011 - Nov 2011 · 7 mos', 'Center for Interdisciplinary research, Paris', 'A project aiming at investigating the existence of nanotubes in B.subtilis and characterizing them with a synthetic biology approach.\u2028Gold medal, Best Presentation Prize and Finalists of the European iGEM Jamboree (Amsterdam); one of the "Sweet sixteen" teams at the iGEM World Championship (Boston)'], ['Variability of a public good production in a clonal population', 'ENS - Laboratory of Statistical Physics (LPS) - Nicolas Desprat', 'Feb 2011 - Apr 2011 · 3 mos', 'To study cooperation in microorganisms, one of the commonly used model is Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This bacteria secrete several siderophores which are used by the whole colony to collect iron in the extracullar environment. One of this siderophore is called pyoverdin. My work during this internship was to set up experimental conditions where the production of pyoverdin is needed for the growth and look, thanks to time-lapse microscopy and image analysis, at the variability of production in clonal population.'], ['Development and analysis of a stochastic model of the extrinsic apoptosis pathway', 'INRIA - contraintes lab - Gregory Batt', 'Nov 2010 - Jan 2011 · 3 mos', 'The goal of the project I was involved in is to model the creation of a synthetic insulin-producing tissue. One of the major challenges consists in controlling the cell density inside this tissue to avoid a constant growth. The developed approach to obtain this homeostasis is to implement a quorum-induced fractional killing by modulating the extrinsic apoptosis variability. During my internship I first used a deterministic computational model to select the best hypothetical engineered genetic networks to modulate extrinsic apoptosis variability. Then I developed several stochastic models to quantify how much variability could we achieve from such engineered system and tested the possibility of quorum-induced fractional killing.'], ['Causes and consequences of protein aggregation in cellular degeneration', 'Inserm U1001, University Paris Descartes - Ariel Lindner', 'Mar 2010 - Jun 2010 · 4 mos', 'Aging in simple organisms is poorly understood and even less in organism with an apparent symmetrical division. E.coli seems to divide in a symmetrical way but some studies have shown a decrease of fitness and increase of mortality rate with time of the old-pole carrying cells, reminiscent of ageing of higher organisms. This old-pole effect can be accounted for to alrge extent by the presence of accumulated damage of protein aggregates. During these 4 month, I constructed several strains to follow these aggregates by Time-lapse fluorescence microscopy. I have also set-up the microfluidic device permitting to follow old pole cells during many generations. In the future, these tools could permit quantitative measurements of protein aggregation and the study of the relation between this protein aggregation process and aging.'], ['Similarity research between E.coli metabolites and drugs thanks to virtual screening', 'Jean-Loup Faulon Lab', 'Jun 2009 - Jul 2009 · 2 mos', 'Evry', 'Production of pharmaceutical drugs can be really costly. Biotechnology production offers a good alternative to chemical synthesis in terms of cost. To determine the best pathway to hijack towards the production of a specific compound, one of the first steps is to find a precursor inside the chassis organism (in this case E.coli). My work during this internship was to use chemo- informatic tools (Molecular signature, Similarity coefficient) to target interesting drugs which could be synthesized in E.coli because of their similarities to existing metabolites. Thanks to my work a list of interesting drugs and their respective pathway suitable to bio-production have been extracted.']]

Name: 8cb64003043a6171d71691d88a0ba3d0
Position: PhD in Evolutionary Biology/Behavioral Ecology/Sensory Ecology/Herpetology
Experience: [['PHD Graduate Student', 'Université de Paris · Contract', 'Oct 2016 - Oct 2019 · 3 yrs 1 mo', 'Paris, France', 'Colour change is not as unusual as often thought. Although the mechanisms allowing colour change are currently largely understood, the evolution of this intriguing ability remains poorly investigated. In chameleons, there is some support for the “selection for social signalling” hypothesis. However, in chameleons, one prediction which states that there should be “More intense sexual selection” remains to be tested. Moreover, the evolution of chameleon colour change has only been investigated at the genus level while the entire family is capable of changing colour. The aims of this thesis are to better understand the evolution of colour change and the evolution thereof. I approach this topic through two main lines of research. First, I investigated the role of colour change in sexual selection in the panther chameleon through an integrative approach combining physiological and performance measurements, behavioural experiments, and colour analysis. Second, I studied the evolution of colour change within Chamaeleonidae. I traced the evolution of colour change using a comparative phylogenetic analysis and explored some of the selective pressures thought to have driven its evolution.'], ['Intern', 'Instituto Pirenaico de Ecologia (IPE)', 'Jun 2016 - Aug 2016 · 3 mos', 'Jaca', 'Behavioral experiments, Herpetology, lizard capture, lizard care, functional morphology measurements (bite force, sprint, head shape) and fieldwork'], ['Intern (IBENS)', 'École normale supérieure', 'Apr 2015 - Jul 2015 · 4 mos', "46 rue d'Ulm 75005 Paris", 'Impact of global warming on the viviparous lizard: demographic and evolutive modeling'], ['Internship student', 'South African National Biodiversity Institute', 'Jan 2015 - Mar 2015 · 3 mos', 'Kirstenbosch, Cape Town', 'Profiling microsatellite loci Cape Dwarf Chameleons (Bradypodion pumilum) from the Western Cape'], ['Internship Student', "Institut d'Ecologie et des Sciences de l'Environnement de Paris (IEES Paris)", 'Sep 2014 - Nov 2014 · 3 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'Physiological response to stress in Zootoca vivipara'], ['Intern at FunEvol team', "Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle", 'Feb 2014 - Jul 2014 · 6 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'Is diet associated with the evolution of head shape and bite force in the chameleon genus Bradypodion?'], ['Intern at FunEvol team', "Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle", 'Oct 2013 - Dec 2013 · 3 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'Morphometric analysis of chameleon fossil fragments from the Early Pliocene of South Africa: a new piece of the chamaeleonid history'], ['Intern at FunEvol team', "Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle", 'Feb 2013 - May 2013 · 4 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'Morphometric analysis of chameleon fossil fragments from the Early Pliocene of South Africa: a new piece of the chamaeleonid history']]

Name: aaf14f67db4b5da4fe4a89097adc9905
Position: Software engineer [Database skills ; hardware-adjascent objectives].
Experience: [['Quality Assurance Engineer', 'fortil · Permanent', 'Mar 2022 - Present · 3 mos', 'Belgium'], ['Programmer (fr: programmeur)', 'Sopra Steria · Apprenticeship', 'Sep 2019 - Sep 2021 · 2 yrs 1 mo', 'Aix-En-Provence Area, France'], ['Engineer In Training (alternance)', 'Polytech Marseille · Apprenticeship', 'Sep 2019 - Sep 2021 · 2 yrs 1 mo', 'Marseille Area, France', "As part of my contract with Sopra-Steria, I spend half my time in academic training (French: Formation par alternance dans le cadre d'un contract professionnel)."], ['PhD student', 'Université de Montpellier', 'Oct 2014 - Sep 2019 · 5 yrs', 'Montpellier', 'My work aimed at bettering our description and understanding of pore nucleation and propagation in bio-membranes (specifically human red blood cells) in the presence of a strong (effective) spontaneous curvature. The core question of my PhD is how the malaria parasite (Plasmodium Falsiparum) gets out of human red blood cells. Although probably "prepared" in advance, the whole egress event takes place within a few hundreds milliseconds. I tested ways to characterize a new type of artificial poration and investigated the roles of the cytoskeleton and the membrane (mostly through perturbative/destructive means). This work has oblique relevance to the egress of erythrocytic stage P. falsiparum (malaria\'s parasite), where poration with membrane curling and "inside-outing" of the plasma membrane has been reported. I am shared my time between two teams (i)"Physique et morphogénèse de la microcirculation" [lab: Centre de Biochimie Structurale]; and (i)"Biogenèse membranaire et interactions avec la cellule hôte chez Plasmodium et Toxoplasma" [lab: Dynamique des Interactions Membranaires Normales et Pathologiques]. My work chiefly included chemical perturbation, microscopic imaging, analysis automation, and handling of human blood. I also designed a gravity pump and worked with (erythrocytic) P. falsiparum cultures.'], ['M2 intern', 'Laboratoire Charles Coulomb (L2C) - Centre de Biochimie Structurale (CBS)', 'Jul 2014 - Sep 2014 · 3 mos', 'Montpellier, France', "(This internship's objectives correspond to the first phase of my PhD project, starting in October 2014) At the end of its red blood cell (RBC) stage, the malarial parasite exits its host erythrocyte. The mechanism of this egress and what leads to it are poorly characterized and understood. The dynamics of this egress have recently been observed[1] and relies on the formation and stabilization of a pore in the membrane. The stabilization is probably partly due to a change in the spontaneous curvature of the membrane, as the membrane curling at the pore border suggests. As a first step to understand what happens in infected RBCs, I will work on creating ans stabilizing pores in healthy RBCs, and will characterize the pore opening process with rapid microscopy (the whole event lasts a few miliseconds). Microinjection and electroporation will be useful for that part. I will also try to obtain the profile of the membrane curling with a good resolution (spinning disc and super-resolution). [1] Abkarian et al., Blood Journal (2011)"], ['M2 intern', 'Institut Pasteur', 'Jan 2014 - Mar 2014 · 3 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'FCS (fluorescence correlation spectroscopy) for neuronal imaging: getting on/off rates of the Ca2+/Fluo-5F pair. The calcium-indicator fluorophore Fluo-5F can be used to track calcium levels in the synapse around neurotransmitter release. What the corresponding measurements give is the interaction of the probe with Ca2+ when competing with endogenous Ca2+ receptors. To extract the dynamical properties of these biological targets, a good knowledge of the probe is needed. My role will be to work on the theory of FCS and analysis tools to extract the on and off rates of the Fluo-5F/Ca2+ coupling from the FCS data. Experimentally, I will start by a titration curve (wich gives access to Kd=koff/kon), then characterize the FCS point spread function (PDF) in the setup, and finally collect FCS data to be analysed.'], ['M2 intern', 'Institut Jacques Monod', 'Sep 2013 - Dec 2013 · 4 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'Caracterisation of a SNARE protein complex activity using a model system. My contribution was to test techniques to synthesize Syn1-GUVs for the use described below. SNAREs are generaly involved in membrane fusion events and several SNARE complexes have been shown to be sufficient for membrane fusion in vitro. The particular complex I am working on (Syn1 - Snap25) is suspected to induce hemifusion (only one monolayer of each bilayer is fused) to enable lipid exchanges, but no full fusion. The proteins are inserted into artificial liposomes (spherical lipid bilayers of controlled composition). For each moietey of the complex, vesicles are prepared. Upon mixing of the two vesicle solution, membrane and content mixing are assessed using fluorescence quenching.'], ['Intern', 'Institut Curie', 'Mar 2013 - Jul 2013 · 5 mos', 'Curie Institute, Paris, France', "Under the supervision of François Quemeneur. Patricia Bassereau's team, UMR168, Curie Institute. Using Giant Unilamellar Vesicles (which are a model of a cell membrane) to test some of the physical properties of membranes, such as the dependence of the diffusion coefficient (of a membrane-embarked molecule) on the local curvature of this membrane. I worked on a (already functional) setup enabling to control the local curvature using micro-pipettes and optical tweezers, and to monitor individual trajectories of embarked molecules by single particle tracking. I also used the same system to monitor lipid bilayers tethers coalescence (merging), and compared my observations to the predictions of an existing model."]]

Experience: [['Psychology Doctoral Practicum Trainee', 'The Adult Skills Center (TASC) · Internship', 'Aug 2021 - Present · 10 mos', 'Los Angeles, California, United States', '•\tProvide individual therapy for adults with cooccurring neurodevelopmental disability and mood disorders. Treatment modalities include CBT, DBT, humanistic, and trans-disability affirmative therapy. As clients hold a number of diverse identities relating to gender/transgender, race/ethnicity, sexuality, and religion, a multicultural approach is integrated into all treatment modalities. •\tCo-facilitate group therapy related to topics: stress management, social skills, money management, and healthy relationships. Assisting in the development and implementation of an adapted DBT Skills System for emotional regulation for people with ID. •\tConduct initial intake assessments for new referrals, as well as client assessment reviews. Regularly collaborate with collaterals and other specialists (OT, ABA, MFT) for treatment coordination. •\tCo-creating Wellness Workshops for TASC clients and staff--psychoeducational workshops designed to improve mental wellbeing through mutual learning, discussion, and exercises. Topics include: mindfulness, burnout, and self-care, to name a few. •\tDeveloping and presenting a staff-wide training on gender and LGBTQIA2S+ identities, and their intersection with disabled/neurodiverse identities, as well as microaggressions and clinical recommendations.'], ['Program Manager II', 'Learning and Behavioral Center LLC · Full-time', 'Oct 2019 - May 2021 · 1 yr 8 mos', 'Greater Los Angeles Area', '·Supervise direct ABA therapy staff to ensure quality clinical practice, develop skillset, and manage clinical interventions at home, school, and center setting ·Create written educational and behavioral protocols for staff to implement in the field based on child’s developmental status and goals, as well as written progress reports detailing student’s evolution ·Conduct staff training for onboarding new behavioral therapists and provide ongoing training and development for experienced staff ·Administer parent group training to give practical behavioral intervention strategies to best support their family and child on the spectrum'], ['Psychology Research Intern and Program Lead', 'Paris Descartes Institut de Psychologie', 'Feb 2019 - Aug 2019 · 7 mos', 'Paris Area, France', "·Researched VR autism training: conducted comprehensive bibliographic reviews, led informational meetings, collaboration, and interviews with autism and VR specialists, and drafted project proposals ·Contributed to research on well-being of educators and parents of children on the autism spectrum: statistically transformed patient data for processing and consequent analysis of results, translated scientific articles and collaborated with authors on scientifically rigorous writing and editing ·Research concluded with my master's thesis, 'Changes in stress measures of parents with an autistic child following a 10-week group parent support program'"], ['MS - Educational Technology', 'CRI - Centre de Recherches Interdisciplinaires', 'Sep 2017 - Jul 2019 · 1 yr 11 mos', 'Paris, France', "I completed 1 year studying the fundamentals of physical life science research to help better understand autism and improve therapeutic outcomes in the Interdisciplinary Approach to Life Sciences Master Year 1 Program. As a culmination of my work, I wrote my Master's thesis, entitled 'Changes in stress measures of individual parents with an autistic child following a 10-week group parent support program.'"], ['Connect Project Lead Intern', 'Institut Pasteur', 'Feb 2018 - Education: [['ESCP Business School', 'Doctor of Philosophy - PhD, Management Control and Performance Processes', '2017 - Dec 2022', "Holistic Approach to Understanding Design, Implementation, Use and Evaluation of Occupational Digital Health Technologies This longitudinal mixed methods case study marries four different areas of research; behavioural health psychology ( specifically in occupational health); digital health ( including design and implementation science), critical digital health and management control to provide a detailed account of the journey of design, development and implementing digital health tools at work. This provides a holistic picture of the use of digital health tools in a work environment, taking into account four dimensions: the design of the technology ( with it's limitations and affordances), the user point of view ( with barriers and facilitators to adoption), the organisational context and the evaluation and performance dimension, providing a deeper understanding of the use of these tools in the modern workplace."], ['Learning Planet Institute', "Master's degree, Interdisciplinary Approaches in Life Sciences/ Approaches Interdisciplinaires du Vivant (AIV) (M.Sc)", '2016 - 2017', 'Activities and societies: Betterncourt iGEM, European Citizen Science, Hello Tomorrow', 'The AIV Masters is an interdisciplinary program tackling quantitative approaches on different interfaces with Life Sciences. It aims at training creative and talented students to develop their research in an environment as enriching as the best world graduate programs. The program is based on learning through research pedagogy – rich with research internships and collaborative projects. The program is funded by the Bettencourt Schueller Foundation. CRI is the first in France to teach systems biology and synthetic biology. The training is focused at the interface of life sciences and physics, mathematics and computer science. Apart from systems and synthetic biology, students discover methods of mathematical modelling, statistical analysis and as well state-of-the-art technologies, used to quantify the properties of living systems. They also gain skills in scientific communication and may want to participate in external modules to acquire or strengthen a specific knowledge.'], ['University of Toronto', 'Honors Bachelor of Applied Science (B.A.Sc.), Majoring in Health and Disease and Medical Anthropology', '2010 - 2015', 'Activities and societies: New College Student Council, S.E.E.D.S , U of T iGEM']]

The Open Wet Lab is a leading place for bio-art, biodesign and do-it-together biology. It works together with artists, designers, scientists, and hackers at public participation projects. The BioHack Academy learns individuals to build their own lab, create bio experiments, and teaches the basics of synthetic biology and critical reflection.'], ['Sales Associate', 'Kilo Shop - Vintage Clothes', 'May 2018 - Jul 2018 · 3 mos', 'Amsterdam Area, Netherlands'], ['Intern', 'Doing It Together Science', 'Feb 2018 - Apr 2018 · 3 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'I was taking part in the DITOs (Doing It Together science) project for France, organizing the DITOs event on the topic of Biodesign in Paris. DITOs is a a three-year EU citizen science outreach project intended to increase public participation in scientific research and innovation. The 11-partner project, coordinated by UCL Extreme Citizen Science group, aims to build the institutional and policy foundations for sustained deep public engagement in science and technology in Europe that enables people to contribute at a level of participation suitable for them. The project implement many innovative participatory event formats across Europe focusing on the active involvement of citizens in two critical areas: the cutting edge topic of biodesign and the pressing area of environmental monitoring. It also advance the EU Responsible Research and Innovation agenda by moving beyond more traditional approaches into direct engagement that builds upon DIY, grassroots, and frugal innovation initiatives so that in the short and medium term we sustain localised capacity building and in the long term the effects of these grassroots efforts channel into policy action at different levels.'], ['Research Assistant', 'Institut Pasteur', 'Oct 2017 - Dec 2017 · 3 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'Cell death and epithelial homeostasis - Dr Romain Levayer Lab Investigating modulation of ERK signaling pathway in Drosophila melanogaster wing imaginal disc In vivo imagery, semi-automated image analysis, statistical analysis (cross-correlation, PCA, GLM) of single cell tracks'], ['Research Intern', 'CNRS', 'Mar 2017 - Jul 2017 · 5 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'Cell wall thickness and cell polarity of Budding Yeast - Nicolas Minc Lab During my internship I used and learnt as methodology live imaging of growing cells and super-resolution microscopy on budding yeast cells, perform genetic crosses and image analysis.'], ['Event Organizer', 'Budapest Botellón', 'Jul 2015 - Sep 2015 · 3 mos', 'Budapest, Hungary'], ['Production Manager', 'Budapest Essentials', 'Apr 2015 - Jul 2015 · 4 mos', 'Budapest, Hungary', 'Budapest Essentials 2015.jpg'], ['Intern', 'INRA French National Institute for Agricultural Research', 'Jul 2011 - Sep 2011 · 3 mos', 'Avignon Area, France', 'The characterization of apricot varieties and hybrids resistance/ susceptibility test to the Sharka disease (Plum Pox Virus) and the validation of Sharka resistant varieties in infected orchard conditions']]

Name: 2382d47eb0e7356835178fbce616aa4c
Position: Joint PhD at KU Leuven and Ghent University
Experience: [['Research Scholar', 'KU Leuven', 'Oct 2019 - Present · 2 yrs 8 mos', 'Belgium', 'The project aims to investigate the role of the interplay between the gut microbiome and their host, Daphnia with respect to the response of the host to an environmental stress factor for cyanobacteria (Microcystis aeruginosa). More specifically, we will use various molecular targeted techniques in combination with whole genome analyses to distangle the contribution of the gut microbiome and DNA methylation in the host to the phenotypic stress responses at the organism level (growth, reproduction and survival). Using this approach we would like to validate the unraveled mechanisms at the protein level using in vitro assays and to delineate the interaction between epigenetics and the microbiome upt to the metabolite and life history phenotypic outcome via an integrated and innovative approach. The innovativity lays in the use of gut transplants and the ability to immediatly link this to targeted gene expression and epigenetics of the host with the composition and gene functions of the microbiome.'], ['Joint PhD', 'Ghent University · Full-time', 'Oct 2019 - Present · 2 yrs 8 mos', 'Ghent, Flemish Region, Belgium', 'The microbiota is the pool of micro-organisms living inside the organism, majorly found in the gut. These micro-organisms play a vital role in shaping the health of an organism through diet (toxic) effects, and also affect host immunity. This study focuses on the role of host-microbiome interactions in shaping the fitness (realized in phenotype and driven by genotype) of Daphnia, an upcoming invertebrate (epi)genomic and microbiome test model. Significance of miRNAs as communication molecules in influencing the host microbiome interaction driven by epigenetic changes in the presence of stressors (Iridovirus and toxic Cyanobacteria) is the prime goal of the project. I aim to unravel this by performing comparative analysis in control and gut transplant experiments with germ-free individuals. The origin of miRNAs will be linked with presence of Transposable Elements (TEs) in specific Daphnia genotypes differing in evolutionary background. I will use an innovative and integrative multi-omics approach: amplicon sequencing, transcriptomics, and epigenomics to decipher the role of miRNAs in structuring the host epigenome which further affects gene expression and phenotype influenced by particular microbiota. I hypothesize that the expression of miRNAs derived from TEs can be linked with DNA methylation patterns to regulate the epigenetic characteristics of Daphnia genotypes and reflect the interaction between the host genome and microbiome upon the exposure to envisioned stressors.'], ['Graduate Student Researcher', 'Institut Pasteur', 'Jan 2019 - Jul 2019 · 7 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'The project establish a robust analytical method for the integration of transcriptional data sets generated in diverse clinical studies. The analysis of the data sets (TB infection (pre/post treatment), with early onset type 1 diabetes (T1D), and juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) (pre/post treatment). In addition to the 1,000 healthy donors of the Milieu Interieur consortium) allow for the cross-comparison of healthy donors from different geographical settings, and the comparison of induced immune responses between infection and autoimmunity.'], ['Graduate Research Intern', 'CRI', 'Nov 2018 - Mar 2019 · 5 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'Stress is one of the key role player leading to arousal, valence and engagement of the person. In the project we are measuring the stress within the IGEM teams during the important final deadline of their project, the wiki freeze. For that purpose, we will record the level of stress using a mobile application that measures heart rate with the smartphone camera, without the need for external pulsometers. This app asks the user to press the smartphone camera lens gently with their finger and, after some seconds, a reading is shown. Then integration of this data with stress hormones level and their engagement, commitment, integration in the team. In this way we are using a holistic approach to understand team behaviours and the most smart way to tackle the stress.'], ['Member', 'iGEM Competition', 'Mar 2018 - Dec 2018 · 10 mos', 'iGEM Paris Bettencourt Foundation, Paris Area, France', 'iGEM Paris Bettencourt Foundation 2018: Antibiotic overuse in livestock industry is one of the major drivers to the antibiotic resistance evolution; motivating calls to reduce, replace, and re-think the antibiotic usage in animals. Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are a promising alternative to conventional antibiotics. Recently, a class of chemically-synthesized, star-shaped AMPs has been shown to exhibit broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity while maintaining biocompatibility with mammalian cells. In this project, we combinatorially fused a set of known AMPs to structurally diverse, self-assembling protein cores to produce star-shaped complexes. Over 200 fusions were designed and expressed in a cell-free system, then screened for activity, biocompatibility, and membrane selectivity. In addition, we selected 4 AMPs for rational mutagenesis (~12000 variants), and a subset of fusions for molecular dynamic modeling, to identify features of surface charge and star geometry that impact AMP performance. Overall, we aim to create a novel class of selective, non-toxic AMPs which are biologically-produced.'], ['Project Intern', 'Inria', 'Feb 2018 - Jul 2018 · 6 mos', 'Rhone-Alpes, France', 'The group developed an E. coli strain that allows the growth rate to be switched on and off externally by adjusting the availability of RNA polymerase, a major component of the gene expression machinery. It was shown that by arresting the expression of RNA polymerase resources are shuttled away from protein synthesis (growth) to the production of a metabolite of interest (glycerol). This proof-of-principle has been extended from the microliter to the liter scale, in collaboration with a biotechnology company, and we have acquired metabolomics, transcriptomics, and proteomics datasets to characterize the physiology of both growing and growth-arrested, glycerol-producing cells. My project was focused on the integration of these datasets using a combination of statistical techniques and a genome-scale flux balance models of E. coli metabolism, in order to study the reorientation of fluxes from growth to glycerol production on the molecular level and the possible occurrence of stress responses. The conclusions drawn from this study lead to further validation experiments with the growth switch. Moreoever, the improvement of some aspects of the system, such as its genetic stability or the induction mechanism, were also explored during the internship time.'], ['Project Assistant', 'IGIB · Full-time', 'Sep 2016 - Aug 2017 · 1 yr', 'New Delhi Area, India']]
Education: [['KU Leuven', 'Doctor of Philosophy - PhD, Epigenetics and microbiota'], ['Ghent University', 'Joint PhD, Microbial and Eukaryotic Genetics', '2019'], ['Learning Planet Institute', "Master's degree, Interdisciplinary Sciences", '2017 - 2019'], ['Université Paris Cité', 'Master of Interdisciplinarity, System and Synthetic Biology', '2017 - 2018'], ['Delhi University', 'Bachelor of Science (B.Sc.), Botany/Plant Biology', '2013 - 2016']]

Name: baaf131b498e7734be21a7ce4dc54324
Position: Engineer at CRI
Experience: [['Engineer', 'CRI · Contract', 'Jun 2021 - Present · 1 yr'], ['Engineer (IE)', 'INRAE · Contract', 'Mar 2018 - Jun 2021 · 3 yrs 4 mos', 'Jouy-en-Josas', '1st project: Development and characterization of recombinant probiotics with therapeutic use against gut inflammation. 2nd project: Characterization of the anti-cancer properties of a probiotic strain on different cell lines. Side projects: Construction of recombinant probiotics; characterization of the anti-inflammatory properties of an enzyme (in vitro).'], ['Co Founder', 'Unibiome (Peer To Peer Probiotics) · Self-employed', 'Jan 2016 - Dec 2017 · 2 yrs', 'Unibiome is developing fermentative microbes that have been engineered to produce vitamins and other healthy compounds, and designed to be used with any fermentation based food to increase its nutritional value. (now closed)'], ['Making antibiotics in E. Coli: function of a ferredoxin', 'Bokinsky lab - TU Delft', 'Jan 2016 - Apr 2016 · 4 mos', 'Delft, Pays-Bas', 'The Bokinsky Lab has engineered E. coli to produce the antibiotics Car, the simplest carbapenem compound, by expressing the necessary three enzymes pathway in E. coli. One of the enzymes, CarC, is a single turnover iron oxygenase enzyme (each reaction inactivates the enzyme), strongly suggesting that CarC activity is regenerated within its native host. Such enzymes are often regenerated by small ferredoxins. Previous experiments in the native host showed that the expression of CarE, found in the native Car biosynthesis gene cluster, dramatically increases production of Car; the same effect was seen in E. coli. CarE is predicted to be a small iron-\xadsulfur cluster ferredoxin, and we hypothesized that it could regenerate the activity of CarC. During this internship, I investigated the mechanism by which CarE could regenerate the enzymatic activity of CarC, using metabolic engineering, proteomics and whole-cell EPR spectroscopy.'], ['Ferment It Yourself - a synthetic biology project', 'iGEM Paris-Bettencourt', 'May 2015 - Sep 2015 · 5 mos', 'Inserm U1001', 'Food fermentation is practiced by every culture in the world, and is especially widespread throughout the Indian subcontinent. Although fermentation enriches foods with some essential vitamins and amino acids, many regions of the subcontinent still suffer from high malnutrition. We addressed this problem by engineering S. cerevisiae and lactobacilli, commonly found in Indian fermented rice dishes, to enrich foods with vitamins A, B2, and B12, and bioavailable iron. We also implemented a differentiation system for reducing the fitness cost of over-expression of multiple pathways, and an easy E. coli sensor for measuring vitamin concentration using a riboswitch. Our user-centered approach incorporates a low-cost and open hardware framework, both for growing and distributing starter cultures, and for quality control. This will give local affected populations power over their own food, as opposed to other GMO nutritional enrichment strategies, by allowing them to grow their own source of vitamins.'], ['Microfluidic development for circulating tumor cells analysis', 'Institut Curie', 'Feb 2015 - May 2015 · 4 mos', 'Institut Curie, Paris', 'Development of a microfluidic platform for the capture of CTCs from very small blood samples.'], ['Sponge Patrol - a synthetic biology project', 'iGEM Evry', 'Jun 2014 - Nov 2014 · 6 mos', 'ISSB - Genopole, Evry, France', 'The sponge can filtrate up to 20m3 of water/day/kg making it one of the most powerful filtrating system alive. Pseudovibrio denitrificans has been shown to be part of several sponges microbiome. Our project was based on the engineering of this bacterium in order to develop a filtrating system allowing to sense and even degrade pollutants in water when cooperating with sponges. My research also included an ethical reflexion on the use of animals as chassis for synthetic biology, and a philosophical reflexion on the rationality versus kludgy-ness of design in synthetic biology.']]

Name: 4f6cec805cc90fc6d37209bd7362510f
Position: Social entrepreneur and designer in accessibility
Experience: [['Intervenant design politiques publiques inclusives', "ENA - Ecole Nationale d'Administration · Self-employed", 'Feb 2020 - Present · 2 yrs 4 mos'], ['Directeur fondateur et Designer de service en Conception universelle', 'SIGNES DE SENS', 'Aug 2003 - Present · 18 yrs 10 mos', '76 BD JB LEBAS 59000 LILLE', "J'ai créé l'association avec des amis en 2003 et nous travaillons depuis sur l'accès aux Savoirs pour les personnes en situation de handicap sensoriel, psychique ou mental. Notre métier quotidien est la création d'outils pédagogiques adaptés pour les publics en situation de handicap et, dans une logique de conception universelle, nous déployons la plupart de nos outils vers le grand public. Aujourd'hui Signes de sens c'est une équipe de 15 personnes et une activité annuelle de 1M€ avec une antenne en Bretagne et des activités sur toute la France. Nous développons notre activité économique dans le respect des valeurs de l'ESS et nous arrivons aujourd'hui à 1/3 de notre budget global assuré par nos recettes propres. Notre plan de développement repose sur 3 leviers : 1- Développer des antennes sur les autres territoires pour fédérer les bonnes énergies et accompagner chaque territoire dans une dynamique d'accessibilité positive et innovante (mettre en réseau les acteurs, déployer notre méthode d'innovation pour l'accessibilité, accompagner et former sur le territoire en cohérence avec les politiques locales et les besoins locaux). 2- Développer notre activité d'édition pour créer plus de produits et permettre à ces produits de se diffuser plus. 3- Construire à Lille le centre d'innovation pédagogique en conception universelle. En tant que directeur, je remplis 2 fonctions très différentes : \t> La direction (pilotage stratégique et développement) \t> La conception d'outils innovants pour permettre l'accès du plus grand nombre à l'information dans des contextes de communication, d'apprentissage ou de relation. J'interviens également dans des mission de conseil, d'accompagnement et de formation pour des acteurs publics et privés. Mon enjeu est surtout d'ouvrir des portes sur lesquelles je peux ensuite former des personnes qui prennent le relai. Je suis un touche à tout, expérimenté en beaucoup de choses mais expert en rien.", 'Signes de sens', 'Depuis 2003, nous imaginons et proposons des solutions pédagogiques innovantes pour tous,en partant des besoins des personnes en situation de handicap'], ['Directeur', 'Les doigts qui rêvent', 'Jul 2017 - Sep 2018 · 1 yr 3 mos', 'Dijon, Bourgogne, France', 'LDQR | Les Doigts Qui Rêvent : Bienvenue\u2009! Iverson (Ph.D., Biochemistry, Department of Biochemistry) Allostery and Conformational Dynamics in Protein Kinase ERK2 Thesis directed by Distinguished Professor Natalie G. Ahn Abstract Extracellular signal-regulated kinase 2 (ERK2) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAP kinase) responsible for regulation of cellular processes such as proliferation, survival, and adhesion. Activation by dual phosphorylation of ERK2 (0P-ERK2→2P-ERK2), as reported by NMR, causes 2P-ERK2 to access a new structural conformer that is in slow (300 s-1) equilibrium with the dominant conformer of 0P-ERK2. I assigned NMR resonances to activation loop residues, and then used these assignments to show by NMR relaxation-dispersion experiments that the activation loop is conformationally mobile on a ms timescale. The dynamics of the loop match those of previously reported global motions in the kinase core that enable productive nucleotide binding. Mutations in the kinase that altered global motions...', 'Activation Loop Dynamics Are Coupled to Core Motions in Extracellular Signal-Regulated Kinase-2', 'The activation loop segment in protein kinases is a common site for regulatory phosphorylation. In extracellular signal-regulated kinase 2 (ERK2), dual phosphorylation and conformational rearrangement of the activation loop accompany enzyme activation.']]

Name: f110add376648697100a8a43fb254127
Position: Ph.D Candidate at MIT
Experience: [['Graduate Research Assistant', 'MIT Civil and Environmental Engineering · Full-time', 'Aug 2020 - Present · 1 yr 10 mos', 'Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States'], ['Graduate Research Assistant', 'MIT Media Lab · Full-time', 'Sep 2018 - Jul 2020 · 1 yr 11 mos', 'Greater Boston Area'], ['Kaufman Teaching Certificate Program', 'MIT Teaching + Learning Lab', 'Feb 2020 - May 2020 · 4 mos', 'Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States', '• Designed a curriculum for the course Engineering Organisms using Backward Design strategy and designed course structure, evaluation components, learning objectives, and documentation. • Actively participated in teaching workshops and contributed to in-class discussions. • Demonstrated successful teaching practices in mock teaching sessions such as evidence-based teaching techniques, engaging and active learning, teaching inclusively, assessing and providing feedback to students, and creating effective course work.'], ['Visiting Researcher', 'Massachusetts Institute of Technology · Internship', 'Apr 2017 - Mar 2018 · 1 yr', 'Greater Boston Area', 'Hatsopoulos Microfluids Laboratory, MIT-MECHE Advisors: Prof. Anette Hosoi, Dr. José Alvarado and Dr. Kaitlyn Hood Project 1: Behavior of deformable hair system in Poiseuille flow - Molded and casted PDMS based deformable hair beds of various packing fractions, and heights. - Designed and fabricated an experimental system to study how deformable hairs behave in Poiseuille flow. - Compared the experimental outcomes with the analytical, and computational solutions. Project 2: Marine crustaceans with hairy appendages: Role of hydrodynamic boundary layers in sensing and feeding (Experiments) - Fabricated rigid hair beds analogous to marine crustaceans’ hairs of various spacing. - Designed and fabricated an experimental system to perform Particle Image Velocimetry studies on flow through rigid hair beds in intermediate Reynolds number regime. - Contributed to a publication where we compared the experimental, and computational outcomes of crustacean hair analogs.', 'Marine crustaceans with hairy appendages: Role of hydrodynamic boundary layers in sensing and feeding', 'Crustaceans use their hairy appendages to sense and track food in flows with intermediate Reynolds number. A reduced order model is developed to predict the flow phase and generate a design principle for engineering flows past hairy surfaces.'], ['Visiting Researcher', 'Ecole Polytechnique · Internship', 'Nov 2016 - Mar 2017 · 5 mos', 'Paris Area, France', "Laboratoire d'Hydrodynamique de l'Ecole Polytechnique (LadHyX) Supervisor: Prof. Charles Baroud Project: Investigation of cell division time of Bacillus subtilis at the single-cell level. - Developed simple agarose and PDMS-based assay to grow cells in a single plane and constrain their movement in the z-direction. - Investigated cell division times of Bacillus subtilis at the single-cell level using confocal microscopy and phase contrast microscopy techniques. Contributed to the attached publication.", 'Growing from a few cells: combined effects of initial stochasticity and cell-to-cell variability | Journal of The Royal Society Interface', 'The growth of a cell population from a large inoculum appears deterministic, although the division process is stochastic at the single-cell level. Microfluidic observations, however, display wide variations in the growth of small populations. Here we ...', 'ladhyx_people.jpg'], ['Team member', 'iGEM Paris Bettencourt 2016 · Internship', 'Jul 2016 - Oct 2016 · 4 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'In this project we produced synthetic enzymes to remove red wine stains from fabric. These enzymes are designed to replace perchloroethylene (PERC), a toxic solvent used in dry cleaning that will soon be banned in France. We listened to people, conducting face-to-face interviews with every single dry cleaner in Paris. From this came a plan for a realistic product, a stain fighting enzymatic pretreatment compatible with existing cleaning technologies and workflows. We isolated microbes capable of degrading red wine from a library of 186 strains taken from vineyard soil samples collected around the world with the help of iGEMers. The most effective microbes were submitted for whole genome resequencing, then analyzed to produce a short list of candidate stain-fighting enzymes. We modeled enzymatic activity at the fabric surface and determined that activity could be substantially improved if the enzymes had a moderate binding affinity for the fabric itself. This effectively increases the enzyme concentration at the fabric surface and reduces the quantity of enzymes lost through diffusion into the medium. We identified short peptides with affinity to cotton, linen, wool, polyester and silk using the method of phage display. The resulting Fabric Binding Domains (FBDs) were quantitatively characterized using ELISA, to determine peptides with optimal affinity as determined by our model. We developed a high-throughput assay to quantify stain removal on real cloth. Laser-cut fabric samples are sealed to 96-well microplates and imaged on flat-bed scanners. We coded custom image analysis software to identify each circular fabric sample and measure the stain intensity. We constructed new BioBricks, fusions of our most promising fabric binding domains to our favorite wine-degrading enzymes. The resulting proteins were expressed, purified and characterized both in vitro (in solution) and in situ (on real stained fabric). For more: http://2016.igem.org/Team:Paris_Bettencourt', 'Team:Paris Bettencourt', 'Centre for Research and Interdisciplinarity (CRI) Faculty of Medicine Cochin Port-Royal, South wing, 2nd floor Paris Descartes University 24, rue du Faubourg Saint Jacques 75014 Paris, France +33 1 44 41 25 22/25 igem2016parisbettencourt@gmail.com 2016.', 'Quantification of bacterial fluorescence using independent calibrants', 'Fluorescent reporters are commonly used to quantify activities or properties of both natural and engineered cells. Fluorescence is still typically reported only in arbitrary or normalized units, however, rather than in units defined using an...', 'Team Picture_iGEM Jamboree 2016', 'The team won Gold medal and Winner of best integrated human practices and nominated for best applied design.'], ['Visiting Researcher', 'Paris Descartes University- INSERM- UMRS1147 · Internship', 'Feb 2016 - Jun 2016 · 5 mos', 'Paris Area, France', 'Group: Translational Research and Microfluidics Group Advisors: Dr. Valerie Taly and Ouriel Caen Collaborators: Prof. Jean Christophe Baret (U. Bordeaux), Prof. Tobias Schneider (EPFL) Project 1: High throughput droplet sorting for 100µm droplet size Project 2: Fluorescent activated multiplexed droplet sorting - Made microfluidic modules such as droplet producers, reinjectors, sorters, pico injectors, and cell encapsulators. - Designed, fabricated, and tested a high throughput droplet microfluidic sorting for mammalian cells. - Designed, fabricated, and tested a highly multiplexed fluorescent activated droplet sorter that can sort five droplet populations. Contributed to the attached publication.', 'High-throughput multiplexed fluorescence-activated droplet sorting - Microsystems & Nanoengineering', 'Droplet-based microfluidics provides new technologies for cell screening by steering cell-containing microdroplets of interest into different channels at the kilohertz frequency. Education: [['Learning Planet Institute', "Master's degree, Master AIRE/Edtech", '2017 - 2020', 'M2 student in Learning Sciences AIRE: Interdisciplinary and Innovative Approaches to Research and Education International interdisciplinary 2-year MSc program dedicated to learning science and digital practicing. Name: 1c442048402523b1c238bb016183664c
Position: Phd-student chez Laboratoire Jean-Perrin / Institut de la Vision / Sorbonne Université
Company: Laboratoire Jean-Perrin / Institut de la Vision / Sorbonne Université
Experience: [['Phd-student', 'Laboratoire Jean-Perrin / Institut de la Vision / Sorbonne Université', 'Oct 2018 - Present · 3 yrs 8 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', 'PhD in Physics applied for Neurosciences Doctoral grant from IPV program (Interface pour le Vivant) Behavioral and neuronal studies of an emerging model: Danionella cerebrum Behavioral experiment, calcium imaging on 2 photon light-sheet microscope'], ['Research Intern', 'ESPCI Paris', 'Apr 2018 - Jul 2018 · 4 mos', 'Paris'], ['Research Intern at Claire Wyart Laboratory - ICM (Institut du Cerveau et de la Moelle épinière)', 'Institut du cerveau et de la Moelle épinière', 'Jan 2018 - Apr 2018 · 4 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', '2nd lab rotation - Master AIV Which factors and circuits drive exploratory locomotion of zebrafish larvae? I am involved in the Claire Wyart laboratory working on two projects supervised by Fang Quang and Hugo Marnass for the behavioural one and by Martin Carbo-Tano for the imaging one and both by Claire Wyart. Arousal locomotion is an essential behaviour for foraging and survival in all species. This spontaneous exploratory locomotion is driven by the excitability of motor circuits in the spinal cord as well as descending commands from the hindbrain. With Martin, we use 2P imagery to determine which is the "minimal" neural circuit needed for slow swim in zebrafish larvae. In parallel, I investigate the impact of peptides on the spontaneous locomotion with Feng and Hugo. Skills developped: -2P imaging -Behavioural study -Zebrafish crossing and maintenance -Pharmocological test -Image analysis'], ['Research intern at Laboratoire Jean Perrin - UPMC', 'Université Pierre et Marie Curie', 'Sep 2017 - Dec 2017 · 4 mos', 'Région de Paris, France', '1st Lab rotation - Master AIV Developing experiments to study the phototaxis strategies of larval zebrafish I am involved in the zebrafish behavior and calcium imagery team under the supervision of Georges Debregéas and his PhD student Sophia Karpenko. The team is interested in understanding how the locomotion in larval zebrafish is modulated by chemical or physical gradient. Fish are inherently attracted by light and tend to swim toward a light source. To do so, fish process luminosity information from its two eyes. Two cases are investigated: - the two eyes receive different luminosity level so the fish uses stereo-visual comparison. The fish can directly turn toward the brighter side. - The two eyes receive the same luminosity level, so the gradient is homogeneous in the fish scale. The fish has to "retain" the first level, then turn, record a new luminosity and compare with the previous one; This is a spatio-temporal sampling and it needs a "memory". I develop two feedback loop assay so as to study these two possible strategies. Thanks to a camera and a projector controlled by program writting by myself, the luminosity level changes or homogeneously in the swim chamber or differs according to the eyes of the fish according to a light source position, randomly chosen. First results confirm a use of the spatio-temporal sampling strategy. Skills developped: -Designing a behavioural experiment from the beginning -Programming in Matlab -Image processing -Analysis and interpretation of results I want to thank Georges and Sophia for their confidences for developing my own experiments and all the LJP for this wonderdul opportunity.'], ['Research Intern', 'UCL', 'May 2017 - Aug 2017 · 4 mos', 'London, Royaume-Uni', 'Developing methods to study modulation of behaviour in larval zebrafish I am involved in the Steve Wilson laboratory, under the supervision of Chintan Trivedi. One of the innate behaviours of larval zebrafish is phototaxis: fish are inherently attracted by light for foraging and avoiding dark areas for fear of predation. Habenula, an evolutionarily conserved structure in the brain modulates this light-preference behaviour in fish. I design a setup to investigate how this light preference behaviour can be modulated by the habenula. So far, I apply my engineering skills to design precisely controlled, computer generated stimuli that can be delivered to larval zebrafish as well as genetically modified mutant zebrafish, which have disrupted habenular nuclei in the brain. These experiments allow me to determine the impact of loss of function in the habenula on light preference, an innate, hard-wired, behaviour. Skills developped: -Design a setup from the beginning -Programming in Matlab -Image processing -Analysis and interpretation of results I want to thank all the zebrafish floor for this amazing and so rewarding experience, and especially Chintan.'], ['Research Intern', 'Arkema', 'Jul 2016 - Dec 2016 · 6 mos', 'Changshu, Jiangsu, China', 'Study all parameters that could influence the hydrophobicity and water whitening resistance of branched vinyl ester modified acrylic polymer -Bibliography -Waterborne polymerization -Contatc angle measurement -Interpretation of results -Oral presentation (to adapt according the public) -International working experience'], ['Team Project', 'ESPCI', 'Apr 2015 - Feb 2016 · 11 mos', 'Paris, ESCPI', 'Bio-orthogonal Reactions Develop some cell living conditions to produce Sonogashira reaction in cell so as to follow the drug path. Organic Chemistry research: -Bibliograpy work -Repeating and analysing synthesis protocol (RMN) -Planning experiences Cell-Biological research: -living conditions -product toxicity'], ['Research Intern', "Laboratoire d'Océanographie de Villefranche-sur-mer (CNRS-UPMC)", 'Jul 2015 · 1 mo', 'Villefranche-sur-Mer', 'Spatial distribution and behaviour of fish larvae: Do they have an orientation feeling? -Field experiences as DISC (Drifting In Situ Chamber, determine the fish larvae orientation thanks to the sun position or costline), fish larvae sampling -Critic speed: Can fish larvae swin faster than current? Results: Diplodus Annularis (33) critic speed of 14 cm/s, sampled in Ligurian sea (25cm/s) Not conclusive Lack of different species -Outcoming analysis (statistics, orientation analysis) Results: orientation with the Sun position: p-value= 0.052. Could be conclusive. Last experiences has a p-value significant -Image sorting (zooplancton) learning set for a neural network to sort plankton pictures from ISIIS (In Situ Ichthyoplankton Imaging System) By definition, plankton flow with the current. Fish larvae are ichthyoplankton so they are driffted by current. However, species are not spread all around the world because fish larvae can swin against currents and angle thanks to the sun. So, is ichthoplankton real plankton?']]

I am involved in setting strategic direction and leading business development and sales effort. In my role, I help organizations interested in African markets, design and execute innovation challenges to solve their market intelligence and product development challenges leveraging the talent in Qiesto's community. This involves a combination of inbound and outbound sales starting with understanding the outcome potential clients are trying to achieve or problems they are trying to solve and then deploying Qiesto's capabilities as an asset they can leverage. Our clients are within and outside the African continent and across sectors. Qiesto is committed to addressing the scourge of youth unemployment & graduate employability plaguing Africa & marginalized communities across the world. We do this by connecting talented youth to opportunities to use and showcase their talent as a pathway to employment and further education. We support education providers with understanding the full competences of their students and in using data to guide them to meaningful careers. We connect forward-thinking organizations with opportunities to crowdsource services, insights & breakthrough ideas from our talent pool which they can also recruit from."], ['Co-creation Hub Nigeria (CcHUB)', '11 yrs 8 mos', 'Non Executive Director', 'Jul 2019 - Present · 2 yrs 11 mos', 'Lagos, Nigeria', "As a co-founder, shareholder and board member in Co-Creation Hub (owner of the 2 most established technology hubs in Africa - CcHub & iHub), I am involved in governance and strategic direction. iHub and CcHub are pioneers in demonstrating the power of Africa's startup ecosystem in solving the many social and business challenges plaguing our continent. After direct involvement in operation for the first 9 years, I have now transitioned to a non-executive Director role.", 'Co-Founder & Director of Innovation Consulting', 'Full-time', 'Oct 2010 - Jul 2019 · 8 yrs 10 mos', 'Lagos, Nigeria', 'I co-founded Co-creation Hub Nigeria (CcHub) and played a key role in building it into the most successful social innovation centre and technology hub in Africa. My role as Director of Innovation involved working with stakeholders to co-create innovative solutions to a wide variety of social and commercial challenges leveraging digital tech. Open Innovation: Successfully delivered open innovation engagements for a wide range of clients including Lafarge, VISA, Oracle, Google, World Bank, DFID, British Council, Union Bank etc. Startup Accelerator: Developed and delivered the curriculum for 7 corporate-funded startup accelerators that worked with 135+ early-stage startups to grow using smart strategies. Our clients included Intel, Microsoft, The Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs & GIZ. I also supported the startups to design & close strategic partnerships with a whole range of multinationals and large NGOs Facilitated innovation and design thinking workshops: for a range of clients including a group of 40 governance focused NGOs, mid-level managers in Nigeria 2nd oldest bank, young social innovators operating in Nigeria’s troubled North East etc Project Design & Delivery: Designed, sold & led execution of several direct impact projects at the intersection of technology and society including GoVote.ng (a vote education platform/campaign used for Nigeria’s 2015 general elections) and SafeOnline.ng (a digital security guide, platform & support system for Nigerian NGOs, media and active citizens) Innovation Consulting: Led consulting teams to deliver services for large corporates looking to stimulate innovation in the operations by activating their staff to innovate or by leveraging ideas from outside the business by connecting to relevant startups Digital Security: Facilitated digital security audits for dozens of media agencies & NGOs across West Africa. Contributed to strategic conversations on digital rights and internet freedom across Africa & the world'], ['Director of Progmme', 'Spin Up Science · Full-time', 'Oct 2021 - Mar 2022 · 6 mos', 'Maynooth, County Kildare, Ireland', 'Supporting deep tech researchers (PhD and MSc) across the Republic of Ireland to spin out their discoveries into new high potential startups. Building an ecosystem to support postgraduate researchers interested in dipping their feet into entrepreneurship'], ['Co-Founder', 'Tender Information Service · Part-time', 'Nov 2015 - Jan 2021 · 5 yrs 3 mos', 'Lagos, Nigeria', "After observing the difficulty associated with getting information about available contracts and tenders in Nigeria, I co-founded Tender.ng to ease this. Tender.ng is Nigeria's intelligent online tenders notification platform that allows individuals/ businesses find and respond to tenders that interest them from across the country. We publish daily tenders from federal, state & local government, private businesses, publicly listed companies, non-governmental organizations (NGO) and academic Institutions. We also ensure businesses receive timely alerts on contracts and procurement opportunities they are qualified for. In my role, I oversee the strategy of the business as well as our small team of contributors. I am also involved in forging strategic partnerships that can help the business grow as well as growth hacking."], ['Co-Founder and Managing Director', 'Africa++', 'May 2007 - Nov 2010 · 3 yrs 7 mos', "I co-founded and managed UK operations of Africa++, an organisation facilitating collaboration activities across sectors and interests as a viable strategy for practically addressing Africa's development challenge. In this role, I organised a monthly meetup for the African diaspora and friends of Africa in London which ran for 2 years I also designed and facilitated collaborations events, liaised with institutional partners, conducted small business advisory, project planning and management."], ['Project Lead, Up Rising Leadership Programme', 'The Young Foundation · Full-time', 'Jan 2007 - Nov 2008 · 1 yr 11 mos', 'London, England, United Kingdom', 'I was recruited as the very full-time staff to set up UpRising Leadership Programme, a youth leadership development organisation to get talented young people from marginalised communities in the UK into public leadership positions. Working with this objective, I developed the setup plan for the project and mobilised needed resources to get it off the ground. I developed the 1-year, action-learning curriculum for the programme which included having the participants set-up and run community projects/campaigns. I also got expert peer review of our curriculum from management training experts, Roffey Park. I managed fund-raising for the programme as well as developing and managing a stakeholder base to support the implementation of the programme. This ensured by the time we commenced, we had funds in the bank for the first 2 years of operations I led the effort to build a brand and promote the new venture including coming up with name and logo, working on the website and recruiting young people who live work and study in East London into the programme for the first 2 years. The pilot of the programme commenced in July 2009 with 64 participants from East London and was opened by the UK Minister for Skills, David Lamy MP. Then UK Prime Minister, Gordon Brown and the leaders of the 2 other major UK political parties David Cameron MP (future PM) and Nick Clegg MP (future Deputy-PM) were patrons of UpRising Leadership Programme.', 'UpRising Leadership Programme', 'This is the website of the UpRising Leadership Programme, the national youth leadership charity that I helped to start in the UK'], ['Learning Space Consultant', 'Bryanston Square Limited · Internship', 'Sep 2005 - Aug 2006 · 1 yr', 'London, England, United Kingdom', "\uf0a7\tWorked on several projects under the UK government's Building School For The Future initiative \uf0a7\tInvolved in delivering vision building exercises and design process with UK schools embarking on new building project to ensure educational transformation."], ['Director for Africa Growth Network', 'AIESEC International · Full-time', 'Jun 2004 - Jul 2005 · 1 yr 2 mos', 'Rotterdam, South Holland, Netherlands', 'For one year I was on the global leadership team of the world’s largest entirely student-run leadership development organisation, AIESEC. It was a very diverse team made up of 18 individuals from 13 countries responsible for global direction and strategy. In my role, I: \uf0a7\tWas directly responsible for the performance of 17 national chapters across Africa. \uf0a7\tCoached national leadership teams on strategic planning, team management, partnership building and servicing and leadership development. \uf0a7\tInvolved in delivering 4 international conferences with participation ranging from 150 to 600 people. \uf0a7\tDrove the global expansion strategy which saw us move into Pakistan, Tanzania and Oman in that year'], ['AIESEC in Africa', '2 yrs 1 mo', 'Regional External Relations Manager', '2003 - 2004 · 1 yr', '\uf0a7\tSet up the African office for AIESEC and managed the set up of a regional project on HIV/AIDS and an intra-African youth exchange programme', 'National President', 'Full-time', '2002 - 2004 · 2 yrs', '\uf0a7\tLed the Nigerian branch of the world’s largest entirely student-run, leadership development organization, AIESEC, for 1 year. \uf0a7\tStrategic and operational management of 13 local chapters and the national executive team. \uf0a7\tDeveloped and delivered 7 national and 2 Africa-wide leadership development conferences for University students. \uf0a7\tOversaw a 70% increase in performance across all our key metrices']]

Name: eaf927ed83716c71bf93a286a60a9acf
Position: Science and Technology Officer at Embassy of France in Australia
Experience: [['Science and Technology Officer', 'French Embassy in Australia', 'Dec 2020 - Present · 1 yr 6 mos'], ['Engineer', 'Office français de la biodiversité · Permanent', 'Sep 2020 - Dec 2020 · 4 mos', 'Pérols, Occitanie, France', 'Developing a shiny application to gather data from the biodiversity monitoring programs in France'], ['PhD: Effects of deer on the soil in the forests of Haida Gwaii', 'Université de Montpellier', 'Oct 2016 - Dec 2019 · 3 yrs 3 mos', 'Montpellier (France) and Vancouver (Canada)', "Thèse en cotutelle entre le Centre d'Ecologie Fonctionnelle et Evolutive à Montpellier et l'Université de Colombie Britannique à Vancouver Joint PhD between the Center of Functional and Evolutionary Ecology in Montpellier and the University of British Columbia in Vancouver. Summary: The past century witnessed a dramatic increase in deer abundance in North America and Western Europe that triggered profound changes in the structure of temperate forests. If these changes are today well characterised, the effects of abundant deer belowground in these forests remain unclear. Deer can interfere with the soil through waste deposition, trampling, and reduction of litter quantity and quality by preferential browsing of palatable plants. What are the consequences of these interactions for the soil? To answer this question, we studied the soil response to the colonisation and removal of Sitka black-tailed deer in the forests of Haida Gwaii. We found that deer slowed-down litter decomposition by reducing litter quality. They also modified microbial community structure and ability in decomposing carbon via soil trampling. Most of these effects became only apparent in the long term, hence questioning the results obtained through short term studies."], ['Investigating the mechanisms behind seasonal changes in the body composition of the mouse lemur', "Museum national d'Histoire naturelle · Internship", 'Apr 2016 - Aug 2016 · 5 mos', 'Brunoy', 'mmaillard_Abstract_Internship_mouselemur_2016'], ['Data analyses to study the Pacific Ocean ecosystem structuration', 'IRD · Internship', 'Jan 2016 - Mar 2016 · 3 mos', 'Nouméa', 'Analyses of seawater spectral properties in the southwest Pacific Ocean - Data treatment with R, matlab and odv - Statistical analysis - Data acquisition: field and lab work'], ['Modelling wheat fungal pathogen epidemiology and evolution under different fertilisation scenarios', 'École normale supérieure · Internship', 'Sep 2015 - Dec 2015 · 4 mos', 'Eco-Evolutionary Mathematics Laboratory', '- Modelling and numerical simulation - Adaptive dynamic - Agro-Ecology', 'Internship presentation'], ['Development of algorithms to study palm-pollinator interactions', 'CIRAD · Internship', 'Apr 2015 - May 2015 · 2 mos', 'Montpellier Area, France', "Umr AMAP: botAnique et bioinforMatique de l'Architecture des Plantes"], ['Summer Internship', "Laboratoire d'Océanographie de Villefranche sur mer", 'Jul 2014 · 1 mo', 'Villefranche-sur-Mer, France', '- Modelling of a marine ecosystem - Field works'], ['Research Internship', 'Newcastle University', 'Feb 2014 - Apr 2014 · 3 mos', 'Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom', 'Bioinformatic analyses of the Rab small GTPase diversity in the human parasite Trichomonas vaginalis', 'Internship report']]
